entry.et: Middle English sloop, probably from aslope, adverb, at an angle

def.dt: :that slants :sloping often used in combination slope-sided
:to lie or fall in a slant :incline
:go travel slopes off into the night Wolcott Gibbs
:ground that forms a natural or artificial incline
:upward or downward slant or inclination or degree of slant
:the part of a continent draining to a particular ocean Alaska's North Slope
:the tangent of the angle made by a straight line with the x-axis
:the slope of the line tangent to a plane curve at a point
:the equation of a straight line in the form y = mx + b where m is the slope of the line and b is its y-intercept
:a gentle incline for skiing used especially by novice skiers called also bunny hill
:the comparatively steep slope from a continental shelf to the ocean floor
:the proper path of descent for an aircraft preparing to land
:such a path indicated by a radio beam
:the radio beam that marks a glide slope
:a course of action that seems to lead inevitably from one action or result to another with unintended consequences
region N Alaska between Brooks Range & Arctic Ocean
